content: hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic
craft it is a new week and it's time to continue on these frost grave resin

mixing so what I did was I remembered that one of these tiles took
approximately one of these shot glasses of resin I multiplied that by 16 and I
wanted to see if that was the right amount so yesterday last night in
preparation for this I actually took the amount of water that I thought would be
the right amount of resin and I poured it in this mold just to see I wasn't
quite right it actually needed more so I played with the amount a little bit
until I got to knowing exactly how much I'm going to need to fill this so very
much worth doing when it's this amount of resin if you get the wrong amount on
a small little thing no big deal but I don't want to mix way too much and have

that all the water was fully dried and there was no moisture on this mold when
pouring the resin doing this made me think about what is likely going to be
the big pitfall in this week's episode and that is simply the amount of resin I

see how far it goes and see where we get I really don't think it's gonna be

end of the world on these tiles for what they are but I think I'm gonna have to

with a pressure pot and vacuum chamber but that's okay this don't turned out

okay a little leveling bed seems to have been a success no spillover this time

good news I have all of my castings complete I had more than enough resin I
had enough to do the nine tiles that I needed and a little bit extra that
allowed me to do two more which is great because those two I'll be able to cut up
and use as my transition tiles that I plan on making in the future from snowy
forest hill whatever to city so no trip to buy resin and no more resin expiring
on my shelf so that's great and it didn't take that long I didn't quite
keep track of time but maybe three or four hours to cast them all which is a
far cry a great improvement over the what 64 hours I predicted if I was doing
them in 3x3 so that pivot was worth it now the bad news is that oh the amount
of little bubbles that I have to pick off these with a knife it's a lot and
it's very time consuming I'm only done about half of them I got another couple
hours of work just doing that and it is boring and tiring and my eyes are
strained and it just kind of sucks this is where not having a pressure pot and a
degassing chamber is totally fine for just doing a few little things but doing
stuff in this quantity trying to do it seriously those are tools that are worth
having and I got to say right now to all of the people who are running resin
casting businesses and doing this in manufacturing man I have a newfound
respect for you guys although I did before and the costs of resin pieces I
understand why they're so expensive one safety tip because I like adding safety
tips when I stupidly hurt myself you know to be careful with a knife but with
resin like this do not aimlessly run your thumb or finger over the very sharp
edge of resin this is like a goddamn razor blade so there's a free tip for
you and get back to picking off bubbles and
clean up my disaster mess of a shop here from pretty sure my camera just

than I thought it would which seems to be the theme of this build spend a few

I'm done I probably missed a bunch now I can start thinking about mounting these
on to MDF so a couple things with that all that effort I put into trying to
square these up on my master was totally futile and useless and a waste of time
and these are definitely not perfectly square and they're not going to line up
nicely as is that's okay however I think what I'm gonna end up doing is ripping
these down slightly on the table saw to make them truly square this gives me one
big advantage actually and that's that when I buy the MDF if I buy a four by
four sheet of MDF I'm not actually gonna be able to get four twelve by twelve
tiles out of it depending on the manufacturer if it's sold as a true
forty eight inch by 48 inches the saw cut is going to make me lose material
and mean that I cannot actually get four pieces out of one 4x4 sheet there's give
me a ton of waste but if I cut these down to slightly smaller say make these
kind of eighth of an inch off each side make the actual finish tiles 11 and 3/4
then I can get more squares under the MDF some MDF is sold slightly oversized
to compensate for this but I'm not sure if quarter inch is like that so that's
good what's bad is that I got to do a ton of work on the table saw and it is
friggin cold outside and I don't want to do it outside the table saw is in the
shed it's gonna be so cold it is too cold to do table saw work outside it's
just not gonna happen I don't have a garage to do it in because I turned my
garage into this room so I guess I'm gonna do it awkwardly in my crappy
basement and for the best that's gonna suck first I

tiles are cut I also cut all my MDF squares but he skipped over filming that

I was a little bit reluctant to cut these on the table saw I was worried

to do in my basement they cut really nicely so now it's just
a matter of attaching the tiles to the MDF squares and then they'll be ready to

of holds they'll never come apart it's very similar to something like no more

these are getting close to completion
getting close to being usable as you can see they can make up a massive gaming
area I've got the 9 1 by 1 tiles so that makes a 3x3 gaming area and then I have
all of the border tiles to turn it into a 4x4 board and where you just see MDF
that will later become big snowy Hills that will transition from snow to the
city streets I made one single one that is a corner
piece so I could do this layout but I also have enough of these side pieces
that I could do a layout where there is a 2x4 section of the full cobblestone
and then for transition and for transition on each side so I can get a
whole bunch of different options out of this the cutting on the table saw
actually works really well because that gave sharp hard edges that make these
tiles but into each other really nicely and overall the thickness variation is
not too bad and they sit pretty nicely next to each other sometimes there are
some spots where there's a thinner tile going up to a thicker one but usually if
you spin it around you'll find a way that it works pretty good so I'm happy
with that overall I still have some bubbles on them that I missed but you
know what I want to say thank you to the commenter on part one who actually said
something pretty brilliant that those bubbles just look like pebbles I never
thought of that so the few that I missed are just going
to look like little pebbles that are locked into the cobblestone so I'm happy
about that I like that good way of thinking I hope
